Energy - policy, planning and administration

Cumulative direct CO2 emission reductions resulting from the GEF-intervention RE-based MWh electricity from the GEF intervention Number of people using RE-based electricity % share of RE in the power generation mix of Barbados Number of strategic plans completed for RE development in Barbados with targets and milestones by Year 2 Number of grid stability assessments on VRE penetration into the Barbados grid by EOP Number of RE licenses that received direct Project assistance by EOP Number of persons attending awareness raising sessions at community centers with regards to the benefits of rooftop solar PV installations that actively seek the introduction of RE in their households/buildings/other infrastructure by EOP disaggregated by sex/gender Number of persons under vocational training programs on solar PV technology and installations that are active in the RE sector by EOP, disaggregated by sex/gender Number of tradespersons who have local certification to construct, assemble, operate and maintain RE technologies that are actively providing ESCO-type/other services by EOP disaggregated by sex/gender MW of rooftop solar PV installations financed through GoB RE funds where DoET and BL&P have involvement in operationalization by Year 3 MW capacity of rooftop solar PV projects in planning and design stages by EOP

comment.narrative: Limited penetration of RE technology, particularly solar PV No effective licensing regime for the utility and distributed RE generation Limited awareness among households and business regarding RE technology Limited availability of low-cost capital for RE investment Lack of capacity and availability of certification for RE technology
1. Carry out installations of solar PV systems at pilot project sites equivalent to a minimum of 85kW 2. Complete development and operationalisation of utility licensing regime

1. The project team, in conjunction with the Division of Energy and Telecommunications (DoET), undertook site assessments of 35 government locations that will be fitted with solar pv systems. The sites were chosen based on their importance as disaster/emergency shelters. The results of the assessments were used to inform the solicitation documents and to provide recommendations for pilot project implementation. The associated procurement process was carried out in collaboration with the DoET, the Ministry of Social Care, Constituency Empowerment and Community Development (MoSCCECD), National Sport Council and the Government Electrical Engineering Department (GEED) and was completed in December, 2016.
2. An intenational consultant was recruited in March to undertake the development of the utility licensing framework. In consultation with the DoET and the ELPA Advisory Committee, a draft utility licence regime that includes generation, transmission and distribution that is appropriate to Barbados was proposed along with a model framework for applications. These documents were presented to government counterparts in September and are awaiting approval.

1. Complete the development and operationalization of utility licensing regime 2. Complete peer review of utility licensing regime 3. Complete installations of solar PV systems at pilot project sites equivalent to a minimum of 85kW 4. Carry out procurement process for the installations of solar PV systems at pilot sites equivalent to a minimum of 65kW 5. Plan and execute the first public awareness campaign 6. Procurement and training in grid modeling software package

1. The review of the deliverables for the consultancy to develop a new utility licensing regime was concluded in the first quarter of 2017. The DoET determined that they lacked the capacity to properly assess the quality of the deliverables from this consultancy. It was agreed that the process would benefit from a peer review of the deliverables.
2. An international consultant was recruited using UNDP's roster of experts. The consultant commenced duties in September. The inception workshop was held with key stakeholders in the energy industry of Barbados. The consultant subsequently reviewed the deliverables of the previous consultancy, the energy policy, market study and ELPA before presenting his comments and recommendations. These comments and recommendations are currently being reviewed by the DoET.
3. The Letter of Award was issued to the successful contractor in March, but, due to lengthy contract negotiations, the contract was signed late September, causing a 6 month delay in implementation. Installation is scheduled to begin in January 2018 after the 45 day material delivery period. In an effort to mitigate against further delay, detailed planning of the installations which include timelines and on site equipment layouts have been carried out during the 45 day material delivery period. Beneficiary engagement has been ongoing to keep beneficiaries abreast of the developments in the project and to encourage buy-in and ownership of the PV systems being gifted to them. Lessons learned have been used in the development of subsequent tender documents. The improved tender documents have been tested on the procurement of smaller systems with great success . Using the improved tender document, 40kW PV systems were procured, installed and handed over within 8 months. Further improvements will be incorporated into the procurement of successive PV systems.
4. The improved tender document was used in the procurement of 65kW of PV systems to be placed on polyclinics

Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

% of targeted beneficiary population know and are able to identify EWS alert messages and respond in an understandable and timely way Number of end-to-end CAP EWS functioning in communities and managed by national authorities, developed using a systematised regional framework Best practices, tools and experiences for implementing CAP-based EWS articulated and disseminated through regional online platform Comprehensive regional process articulated for implementing CAP EWS based on experiences Number of new EWS case studies developed and shared on active regional knowledge platform Number of countries in the region which recognise the integrated EWS model and commit to its adoption in the future

comment.narrative: Countries do not have preparedness systems in place to effectively address the consequences of and response to natural hazards Inadequate Number of end-to-end CAP EWS functioning in communities and managed by national authorities Communities are unable to identify EWS alert messages and respond in an understandable and timely way Lack of comprehensive regional process for implementing CAP EWS No current active regional knowledge platform

1. Development of online platform on EWS 2. 7 country experiences captured through development of case studies 3. 1 regional workshop of EWS convened 4. VCA and EWS assessments completed in at least 2 communities 5. KAP surveys conducted in at least 2 communities 6. End to end EWS system functional in at least 2 countries

i. EWS toolkit information has been uploaded to the CDEMA website but some adjustments are still being made. Focus will continue to be on dissemination and informing partners of the toolkit development. Please view current toolkit at http://www.cdema.org/ under the CRIS section (left hand side of page). A more prominent infographic is currently being developed which will be placed on the website to link directly to the toolkit information. ii. EWS case studies are currently under development. Case study for Anguilla is finalised and awaiting upload to the toolkit. Draft case studies for Saint Lucia received and currently being reviewed. iii. Regional EWS meeting successfully convened after joint collaboration with IFRC, CADRIM, UNISDR, CDEMA and UNDP during 14 -16 April 2016. This workshop facilitated a 1) Shared understanding of the status of EWS in the Caribbean and requirements of key partners to successfully implement EWS in the Caribbean; 2) Increased awareness and capacity among regional and national partners for the successful implementation of EWS; 3) Awareness raised on the need for the consideration of vulnerable groups in the development and implementation of EWS and; 4) Deeper understanding of Partners/country representatives on the requirements needed to operate and maintain CAP Based EWS. 60 participants from the English, Spanish and French speaking Caribbean attended the workshop with the workshop also assisting with the development of the toolkit and case studies envisioned under the initiative. iv. Through collaboration with UNDP Cuba the initiative co-financed the Director of the Department of Instruments and Observation of the Meteorological Institute of Cuba to share the Cuba experience at the EWS regional meeting. v. The initiative supported the IFRC in contracting of a consultant to undertake a EWS desk review to consolidate the knowledge and experiences of EWS in the Caribbean. vi. comment.narrative: High per capita CO2 emissions Few RE/EE strategies and assessments with specific targets High risks associated with investment in RE/EE technologies Limited employment opportunities in RE/EE fields Limited expertise in RE/EE technologies High capital costs and limited availability for RE investment

1. Undertake analysis of national waste management planning and development of relevant management strategies 2. Complete distribution and transmission grid assessments 3. Launch the Online Platform 4. Investment in pilot RE/EE projects as a basis for up-scaling and replication

1. The project team worked to develop an Integrated National Waste Management Strategy for Grenada. One of the issues to be addressed is the need for future disposal capacity. An approach being considered is the construction of a new landfill and an assessment was undertaken to determine the feasibility of waste to energy technology for Grenada. This assessment will be fed into the national Energy policy.
2. The project team undertook a grid integration study for the purpose of assessing the integration of a potential geothermal energy project with the existing diesel and hydro generation on the main island of Saint Vincent in order to evaluate the impacts on the stability and reliability of the electricity grid.
3. The CARILEC platform was completed and launched in July of 2016 as the CARILEC Renewable Energy Community (CAREC).
4. The project team managed the tender process for 17MW system in the Bahamas as well as for equipment for two Belize Hospital energy retrofits. The team also prepared tender documents for a 3-MW Solar PV project near the international airport in Vieux Fort, St. Lucia.

1. 2 countries implementing plans/strategies/policies to achive low-emission objectives 2. Training of local counterparts to partake in RE/EE developments, disaggreated by sex 3. 85 MW installed capacity; 209 MW of committed RE capacity 4. Support to Belize for 80% RE penetration 5. Complete feasibility studies in Bahamas 6. Development of future energy scenarios in Grenada

1. Integrated Resource Plans and National Energy Transition strategies completed for St. Lucia and St. Vincent which are energy transition action plans informed by independent technical analysis that lays the foundation for a sustainable, reliable, cost-effective and equitable electricity sector using the island's local resources.
2. Through its direct support to the CAREC platform, 11 training sessions were undertaken with a total of 490 participants, including 196 females
3. In close coordination between the Government of Saint Lucia and LUCELEC, the project team completed project development for a 3KW solar photovoltaic installation at the Vieux-Fort Airport.
4. Consolidated Project Plan completed and a load study for St. George's Caye was completed.
5. No progress has been made in this area due to misalignment between Government and the utility
6. No progress has been made in this area due to misalignment among the needs of in-country counterparts
